item.title: Item-32 Make sure public inheritance models "Is-A"
item.description: Everything that applies to base classes must also apply to derived classes in public inheritance, for every derived class object is a base class object.

item.title: Item-31 Minimize compilation dependencies between files
item.description: To minimize compilation dependencies, depend on declarations instead of definitions via techniques such as Handle classes and Interface classes.

item.title: Item-30 Understand ins and outs of inlining
item.description: Limit most inlining to small, frequently called functions to facilitate debugging and binary upgradability, minimize potential code bloat, and maximize the chances of greater program speed.

item.title: Item-29 Strive for exception-safe code
item.description: Exception-safe functions leak no resources and allow no data structures to become corrupted, even when exceptions are thrown. Such functions offer the basic, strong, and nothrow guarantees.

item.title: Item-28 Avoid returning handles to object internals
item.description: Avoid returning handles to object internals to increase encapsulation, help const member functions act const, and minimize the creation of dangling handles.

item.title: Item-27 Minimize_casting
item.description: Avoid casts and develop a cast-free alternative whenever practical, especially dynamic_cast in performance-sensitive code.

item.title: Item-26 Postpone variable definitions as long as possible
item.description: Postponing variable definitions as long as possible increases program clarity and improves progranm efficiency.

item.title: Item-25 Consider support for a non-throwing swap
item.description: When std::swap would be inefficient for your type,provide a non-throwing swap member function, a non-member swap calling the member, and possibly a specialized std::swap for the case of classes (not templates).

item.title: Item-24 Declare non-member functions when type conversions should apply to all parameters
item.description: If we need type conversions on all parameters to a function including the one pointed to by the this pointer, the function must be a non-member.

item.title: Item-23 Prefer non-member non-friend function to member function
item.description: Prefer non-member non-friend functions to member functions for better encapsulation, packaging flexibility, and functional extensibility.

item.title: Item-22 Declare data members private
item.description: Declaring data members private gives clients syntactically uniform access to data, affords fine-grained access control, allows invariants to be enforced, and offers class authors implementation flexibility.

item.title: Item-21 Don't return a reference when we have to return an object
item.description: Never return a pointer or reference to a local stack object, a refenrence to a heap-allocated object, or a pointer or reference to a local static object if there is a change that more than one such object will be needed (item 4 provides a “counter” example that is reasonable in single-threaded environments).

item.title: Item-20 Perfer pass-by-reference-to-const to pass-by-value
item.description: Pass by reference-to-const is typically more efficient than pass by value and avoids the slicing problem.

item.title: Item-19 Treat class design as type design
item.description: Before definining a new type, be sure to consider all the issues discussed in this item.

item.title: Item-18 Make interfaces easy to use correctly and hard to use incorrectly
item.description: Good interfaces are easy to use correctly and hard to use incorrectly.

item.title: Item-17 Store newed objects in smart pointers in standalone statements
item.description: Failure to do this can lead to subtle resource leaks when exceptions are thrown.

item.title: Item-16 Use the same form in corresponding uses of new and delete
item.description: If you use [] in a new expression, use [] in the corresponding delete expression; If not, no [] in the matching delete expression.

item.title: Item-15 Provide access to raw resource in resource-managing classes
item.description: Each RAII class should offer a way to get at the resource it manages.

item.title: Item-14 Copy behavior in resource-managing classes
item.description: Copying an RAII object entails copying the resource it manages, so the copying behavior of the resource determines the copying behavior of the RAII object.

item.title: Item-13 Use objects to manage resources
item.description: Use RAII objects such as tr1::shared_ptr and auto_ptr to prevent resource leaks.

item.title: Item-12 Copy all parts of an object
item.description: Be sure to copy all of an object’s data members and all of its base class parts.

item.title: Item-11 Handle self assignment in operator=
item.description: Solve self assignment situation in operator= by comparing addresses of source and target objects, careful statement ordering, and copy-and-swap.

item.title: Item-10 Have assignment operators return a reference to *this
item.description: As title suggests.

item.title: Item-9 不要在构造函数和析构函数中触发虚函数
item.description: 不同于Java或者C#,在C++中构造函数和析构函数里的虚函数不会实现多态的效果。

item.title: Item-8 Prevent exception from leaving destructor
item.description: It is discouraged practice to emit exceptions from destructors.

item.title: Item-7 Declare destructor virtual in polymorphic base classes
item.description: If a class has any virtual functions (for polymorphic purpose), it should have a virtual destructor.

item.title: Item-6 Disallow unwanted compiler-generated functions
item.description: Declare unwanted member functions private without implementations to disallow functionality automatically provided by compilers.

item.title: Item-5 What functions C++ silently generates
item.description: Compilers may implicitly generate their own versions of default constructor, copy constructor, copy assignment operator, and destructor.

item.title: Item-4 Initialize objects before they're used
item.description: Since C++ is fickle about initialization, some good coding style is suggested.

item.title: Item-3 Use const whenever possible
item.description: Useful tips on using const in C++.

item.title: Item-0 Federation of languages
item.description: C++ is a multiparadigm programming langrage.

item.description: Some tips about <iostream>
